page.title: 10CHALKPITS
page.content: The steepness of the{South Downs {escarpment}in this area has made the cutting of chalkpits both easy and cheap. The chalk was{used to produce {cement,}though farmers also took it for making tracks. Now{all the pits have been{closed,}some recently, others before living memory. At Offham the chalk was loaded on to a furnicular railway and sent down to barges on an arm of the River Ouse specially cut for the purpose in 1790. {Nowadays the pits are used for play, mostly by children who climb, hunt fossils, pick blackberries and look at wild flowers. Their bumpy surface also makes the pits good for sledging and bicycle stunt riding. The chalk is very crumbly, especially after rain, so people using the pits have to be very careful.{Accidents}at disused chalkpits are quite common.
